review.title: How much is said in a microblog? A multilingual inquiry based on Weibo and Twitter
review.abstract: This paper presents a multilingual study on, per single post of microblog text, (a) how much can be said, (b) how much is written in terms of characters and bytes, and (c) how much is said in terms of information content in posts by different organizations in different languages. Focusing on three different languages (English, Chinese and Japanese), this research analyses Weibo and Twitter accounts of major embassies and news agencies. We first establish our criterion for quantifying "how much can be said" in a digital text based on the openly available Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the translated subtitles from TED talks. These parallel corpora allow us to determine the number of characters and bits needed to represent the same content in different languages and character encodings. We then derive the amount of information that is actually contained in microblog posts authored by selected accounts on Weibo and Twitter. Our results confirm that languages with larger character sets such as Chinese and Japanese contain more information per character than English, but the actual information content contained within a microblog text varies depending on both the type of organization and the language of the post. We conclude with a discussion on the design implications of microblog text limits for different languages.

sections.heading: 1. ARBITRARY CHARACTER LIMITS?
sections.text: Microblogging platforms differ from traditional blogging platforms in that they have a limit on the length of posts. Such length restrictions are reported to reduce the time and thought needed to create new content and allow for a faster and more timely exchange of information. Indeed, most studies examining the impact of length restrictions on the user experience of microblogging do contain English-language content, but there is sufficient reason to believe that a universal length restriction on Twitter has different effects on people writing content in different languages. It has been reported by major media outlets such as the BBC [13] and Atlantic [29] that much more content can be expressed in languages other than English within a given character limit, notably Twitter's 140-character limit and the 140-byte limit on short message services (SMS or text messages). Chinese [2] and Japanese [33] are often cited as examples of more "expressive" languages within such spatial restrictions.

sections.heading: 2. METHODS AND DATA SELECTION
sections.text: We propose a systematic step-by-step approach that can be extended to other platforms, languages and types of microblogs, with the aim of answering our three main research questions. We focus on news and diplomacy accounts because we expect the length of messages to be an integral part of overall communication strategies, even in potential linguistic or intercultural scenarios. The data selection in this post is limited to two platforms, three languages and the recent contributions of 54 microblogs. However, as the first multiplatform and multilingual study, their contributions are important and lay the foundation for future work with additional account types, languages and platforms. The following sections describe the three steps of the research process, each of which answers one of our research questions: (a) how much can be said, (b) how much is typed and posted, and (c) how much is said in different languages by different organizations.

sections.text: The results of the first subsection confirm that Chinese and Japanese contain more information per character.
